description: 1520s, original sense “lowest note of musical scale”, from Medieval Latin gamma ut, from gamma (“Greek letter, corresponding to the musical note G”) + ut (“first solfège syllable, now replaced by do”). In modern terms, “G do” – the first note of the G scale. Meaning later extended to mean all the notes of a scale, and then more generally any complete range.

examples: She delivered a striking performance that ran the gamut of emotions, from A to B.

entries.meaning: (music) All the notes in a musical scale.
All the colours that can be presented by a device such as a monitor or printer.
